page.title: 03ECOLOGY OF BLACKMORE VALE
page.content: This low-lying open pasture land with deep alluvial soil and good rainfall supports many excellent dairy farms. Friesian cattle were introduced sixty years ago.Many herds have one or two Guernseys to improve the quality of the milk.Artificial insemination is popular and the bull calves are reared for beef. Cheese,once made by the farmer's wife is now produced in the noted factory in Sturminster Newton,the milk being transported in bulk by tanker. Only one farm keeps a few poultry. Formerly each family would farm its own land employing labourers who lived in farm cottages.Now a big farm can be part of a combine and being fully mechanised needs only 3 workers.The farmhouses are let to incomers and the cottages sold to retired folk or week- enders.All are well modernised.
